subject: RE: [junit] Test glossary?
msgSnippet: ... A commonly used glossary of terms such as these and more is the British testing standards organization s BS 7925-1:
messageBody:
> From: Herr Christian Wolfgang Hujer [mailto:Christian.Hujer@...]
>
> I'd like to know wethere there's a comprehensive Unit Testing
> Glossary out there, explaining at least:
> Dummy
> Mock
> Stub
> Different kinds of Tests (Unit, Performance, Integration,
> Interaction, System, Functional, Acceptance, Component etc.
> etc.)
> Invariants, Preconditions, Postconditions
> When to use Exceptions, when to use internal Assertions, when to use Unit
> Tests.
>
> Is there such a glossary?

A commonly used glossary of terms such as these and more is the British testing standards organization's BS 7925-1: http://www.testingstandards.co.uk/bs_7925-1.htm. On that page you can get a free copy of the pre-final draft, and also link to the "living" glossary online.

I've preferred to check out multiple sources for a lot of testing terms, and use them to help me decide based on my experience and own thought. Basing one's theory of the world *just* on given dictionary definitions is thoughtless and careless, in my opinion. But a glossary can be a good start. Books by Binder, Beizer, Myers and Hetzel are great sources for good QA terminology, but they sometimes disagree, which is where you have to think for yourself.

I wrote up a survey of load testing terminology and my own conclusions in this QA newsletter last year, if interested: http://www.soft.com/News/QTN-Online/qtnsep02.html

Scott Stirling
